name: Ryan Florence
tweet: So an interesting side effect is that in order for your page to work the way you expect, you're pushed into  http best practices (whether you know it or not), which then ensures your SameSite cookies actually protect you from CSRF (no mutations in GET).

name: Ryan Florence
tweet: In @remix_run we have two primary server side hooks:  loader (for GET) action (for POST and friends)  This isn't just nice to think about, but things like SameSite cookies are designed with the assumption you aren't going to log somebody out with a GET, opening up CSRF attacks.

name: Joel R. Kallman
tweet: Customer: I'm worried about APEX session ID-guessing attacks  @chrisneumueller: Common misconception. ID is used as simple CSRF token that is enabled even when app does not use checksum protection. Should also consider session cookie - 18 random bytes, base64-encoded.  #orclapex

name: Niklas B
tweet: @_martinthoma the beauty of CSRF and what sets it apart from other bug classes in my opinion is the fact that it can be used to attack web sites to which the attacker doesn’t even have access. So isolation - which solves essentially all other security issues - does not help.

name: ϻг_ϻε
tweet: CVE-2021-24085 is about a user w/ the “Exchange Server Certificates“ role that can access the root cert w/ private key and generate CSRF tokens. Those tokens can be used to trigger a CSRF attack that could lead to an account takeover and the vector could be delivered via email.

name: Sophie Alpert
tweet: Why is there not a cookie SameSite value for "don't send in cross-origin POSTs, do send in cross-origin iframes"?  AFAIK, the former is big for security (preventing CSRF), the latter is not really (clickjacking I guess) – so people with iframes still would want the first half.

name: NoticiasRobloxianas 🏆
tweet: "El X-CSRF-Token es un token que es de corta duración y único. Cuando se envía una solicitud a un sitio API y el encabezado de la solicitud X-CSRF-Token no es válido, la solicitud se rechaza y el encabezado de respuesta X-CSRF-Token se agrega con el token de corta duración"

name: NoticiasRobloxianas 🏆
tweet: Un nuevo ticket que #Roblox ha estado trabajando para aumentar la seguridad del API de la plataforma llamada  X-CSRF-Ticket para la pagina web!  Este ticket parece ser el causante de estos últimos errores de "Error HTTP 403 o Error 400" a través de #Roblox! ⚠ Mas información: ⬇

name: HΔKLUKΞ
tweet: - Try building the payload with multiple methods including a standard HTML form, multipart form, and XHR (Burp can help)  Being thorough is the key - many devs are still implementing CSRF protections on a per-endpoint basis. When they do that, they're bound to forget somewhere!

name: HΔKLUKΞ
tweet: There is still SO MUCH CSRF to find in bounty programs.  CSRF comes in many forms. Try:  - Removing the token parameter entirely - Setting the token to a blank string - Changing the token to an invalid token of the same format - Using a different user's token  More in thread 👇

name: HΔKLUKΞ
tweet: The "generate CSRF payload" feature in Burp Suite is perfect for easily building  JavaScript payloads to escalate XSS.

name: Jake Williams
tweet: In my opinion (take it for what little it’s worth), the realistic (I’m not burning an 0-day) threat of QR codes is mostly CSRF related.  A QR CSRF exploit can only be effective if many people are logged in to a popular service that is vulnerable to CSRF (tiny attack surface).

name: Graham Sutherland (Polynomial^DSS)
tweet: The script keeps web requests to a bare minimum. One request to grab the CSRF token, then one additional request each time you click a part. Part data is cached until you hit refresh, even if you navigate between result pages.

name: Graham Sutherland (Polynomial^DSS)
tweet: The reason this works is because TM (& GM) scripts can make exclusions to the cross-origin security policy, in order to pull the CSRF token from the LCSC webpage and then make API requests to their servers.

name: bend theory
tweet: Ever wonder why param brute forcing is useful? I’ve found tons of vulns with hidden params  GET CSRF: next, continue SQL Injection: docid IDOR: acctnum XSS: pageName, debugtext, errormsg  Param miner was built to find cache poising bugs but it can do much more!  #BugBountyTips

name: Harsh Bothra
tweet: (3/n)  6. Lack of Brute-Force Protection: Possible to brute-force any length 2FA Code.  7. Missing 2FA Code Integrity Validation: Code for any user acc can be used to bypass the 2FA 8. CSRF on 2FA Disabling: No CSRF Protection on disabling 2FA, also there is no auth confirmation.
